notes: Wales uses the Renting Homes (Wales) Act 2016, which replaced the Housing Act 1988 for Wales. Contract holders (not tenants) and landlords use different terminology and grounds. This file requires legal verification against current Welsh statute.

serious_rent_arrears.title: Serious Rent Arrears (Mandatory)
serious_rent_arrears.description: At least 2 months' rent unpaid at both the date of notice and date of hearing for monthly payments, or 8 weeks' rent for weekly payments.
required_evidence: Proof arrears meet threshold at notice date
Proof arrears meet threshold at hearing date
serious_rent_arrears.notes: Most common mandatory ground. Arrears must meet threshold at BOTH notice and hearing dates.

persistent_rent_arrears.title: Persistent Rent Arrears (Mandatory)
persistent_rent_arrears.description: Rent arrears equivalent to 2 months' rent (monthly tenancy) or 8 weeks' rent (weekly tenancy) have accrued at least three times in the past 3 years.
required_evidence: Rent account showing pattern of arrears
Documentation of at least 3 instances of arrears threshold being reached
Proof of arrears history over 3-year period
persistent_rent_arrears.notes: Addresses repeated arrears even if currently paid. Pattern of behavior ground.

some_rent_arrears.title: Some Rent Arrears (Discretionary)
some_rent_arrears.description: Some rent is unpaid at the date of notice and at the date of hearing, but less than the serious arrears threshold.
some_rent_arrears.notes: Discretionary ground. Court considers reasonableness, tenant's circumstances, and proportionality.

breach_of_contract.title: Breach of Occupation Contract
breach_of_contract.description: The contract-holder has broken a term of the occupation contract (other than non-payment of rent).
required_evidence: Copy of occupation contract showing term breached
Evidence of breach (photos, correspondence, witness statements)
Record of landlord's attempts to remedy
breach_of_contract.notes: Common breaches: unauthorized occupants, pets against contract, subletting, property condition.

antisocial_behaviour.title: Anti-Social Behaviour or Criminal Activity
antisocial_behaviour.description: The contract-holder or person residing in or visiting the property has engaged in conduct causing nuisance or annoyance, or has been convicted of certain criminal offences.
required_evidence: Incident logs from neighbors or landlord
Police reports or crime reference numbers
antisocial_behaviour.notes: Includes nuisance, illegal use of property, criminal conviction, domestic violence. Court considers severity.

property_deterioration.title: Deterioration of Property
property_deterioration.description: The condition of the dwelling has deteriorated due to acts of waste or neglect by the contract-holder or other occupiers.
property_deterioration.notes: Excludes fair wear and tear. Must show deliberate or negligent damage beyond normal use.

false_statement.title: False Statement Induced Grant of Contract
false_statement.description: The contract was granted on the basis of a false statement made knowingly or recklessly by the contract-holder or someone acting at their instigation.
required_evidence: Application form or documents containing false information
Proof statement was material to granting the contract
Evidence contract-holder knew statement was false
false_statement.notes: Common examples: false employment, false references, undisclosed pets, undeclared occupants.

suitable_alternative_accommodation.title: Suitable Alternative Accommodation Available
suitable_alternative_accommodation.description: Suitable alternative accommodation is or will be available to the contract-holder when the possession order takes effect.
required_evidence: Proof accommodation is suitable (size, location, facilities)
suitable_alternative_accommodation.notes: Rarely used in private sector. More common in social housing reorganization.

section_173_no_fault.description: Section 173 notices are no-fault notices available after the fixed term ends. They do not require grounds to be specified, only proper notice period.
section_173_no_fault.notes: Section 173 replaced Section 21 in Wales. Unlike fault-based grounds above, no reason required. Notice period depends on occupation contract type and length of occupation. Standard contracts: 6 months minimum occupation before notice can be served, then 6 months' notice required. Cannot be used in first 6 months of occupation.

verification_required.warning: This file is based on legal research but requires verification by a Welsh property law specialist against the current Renting Homes (Wales) Act 2016 statute and any amendments.
verification_required.recommended_review_frequency: Every 6 months or when Welsh housing law changes
